{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Chenpeng Village Primary School stabbing | image = China knife man attack school.png | caption = Footage of the attack significantly contributed to wide-spread news coverage | date = {{Start date|2012|12|14|df=y}} | time = Reported to police at 07:40  [[GMT+8|Beijing Time]] | timezone = GMT+8 | location = Chenpeng ({{zh|s=陈棚村|t=陳棚村|p=Chénpéng-cūn}}), [[Wenshu Township]],
{{nowrap|[[Guangshan County]], [[Henan]], China}} | coordinates = {{coord|31|55|27.19|N|114|46|4.58|E|type:event_region:CN-41|display=inline,title}} | susperp = Min Yongjun | target = Students and an elderly woman | weapons = Kitchen knife | fatalities = 0 | injuries = 24 | motive = }} On 14 December 2012 between 7 and 8 a.m. [[Time in China|local time]], a 36-year-old villager identified as Min Yongjun stabbed 24 people, including 23 children and an elderly woman,[http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2012-12/18/content_16027099.htm Suspect in school knife attack 'feared end of the world'], ''[[China Daily]]'' (18 December 2012) in a knife attack at Chenpeng Village Primary School ({{zh|s=陈棚村完全小学 |t=陳棚村完全小學 |p=Chénpéng Cūn Wánquán Xiǎoxué}}{{#tag:ref|"Chenpeng Village Complete/Total Elementary School" meaning it covers years one through six|group=note}}), [[Wenshu Township]], [[Guangshan County]], [[Henan]] province, China.{{cite news| url= http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90882/8059161.html|title= 22 students injured in central China knife attack|work=People Daily|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=21 December 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1025442/china-children-hurt-in-school-knife-attack|title=China: Children Hurt In School Knife Attack |publisher=Sky News|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2012}} The children targeted by the knifeman are thought likely to be between six and eleven years of age. The attack occurred as the children were arriving for classes probably at 8:00 or maybe even 9:00. The incident has followed other [[school attacks in China (2010–2012)|school attacks in China since 2010]] by [[mental disorder|mentally disturbed]] perpetrators involved in personal disputes or unhappy with the rapid changes occurring in Chinese society.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/15/world/asia/man-stabs-22-children-in-china.html?_r=2&|title=Man Stabs 22 Children in China|newspaper=The New York Times|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2012}} [[Security guards]] had been posted at schools across China,{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/12/14/china-knife-attack-school.html|title=China stabbing spree hurts 22 schoolchildren|work=CBC News|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world-news/china-deploys-security-guards-in-schools-to-avoid-bloodbath-repeat_100421452.html |title=China deploys security guards in schools to avoid bloodbath repeat |publisher=Thaindian.com |date=1 September 2010 |accessdate=15 December 2012}} with all schools to have a security guard by 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world-news/china-to-deploy-more-security-guards-at-schools_100638848.html |title=China to deploy more security guards at schools - Thaindian News |publisher=Thaindian.com |date=17 August 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2012}} ==Stabbing== Due to [[firearm ownership law in China|strict gun control laws in China]], knives are usually the weapon of choice in violent crimes.{{cite news | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-man-slashes-22-children-near-china-school-20121214,0,6383015.story | title = Man slashes 22 children near China school | author = John Hannon | date = 14 December 2012 | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] }} The attack on the children occurred at the entrance of the school.{{cite news|url=http://presstv.com/detail/2012/12/15/278109/22-schoolchildren-stabbed-in-china/|title=Mentally challenged man stabs 22 schoolchildren in China|work=Press TV|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2012}} Min first targeted the elderly woman, aged 85, who lived next to the school. He went to her house at around 7 a.m., stole one of her knives and attacked her head. The woman's daughter said an argument had occurred. At around 7:40 a.m., Min pursued the children with the knife he had stolen from the elderly woman's house and slashed them, many on their heads.{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-12/14/c_132041711.htm|title=22 students stabbed in central China attack|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date=14 December 2012|accessdate=14 December 2012}} ''Xinhua'' reported that some of the children had had fingers or ears cut off in the knife attack.{{cite news | url = http://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/15/china-calls-for-no-delay-on-gun-controls-in-u-s/ | title = China Calls for ‘No Delay’ on Gun Controls in U.S. | author = Mark Mcdonald | date = 15 December 2012 | work = [[International Herald Tribune]] }} Min was restrained at the primary school, and transferred to police custody. The victims were treated at three hospitals. Two of the children were taken to hospitals located outside [[Guangshan County]] to receive better care.{{cite news | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-20723910 | title= China school knife attack in Henan injures 22 children | publisher= [[BBC News]] | date= 14 December 2012 }} None of the victims were fatally wounded.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2248054/China-stabbing-22-children-elderly-woman-stabbed-outside-primary-school-Chinese-knifeman.html | title=22 children and elderly woman stabbed outside primary school by Chinese knifeman | last=Vinter | first=Phil | date=14 December 2012 | accessdate=20 May 2015 | location=London | work=Daily Mail}} ==Perpetrator== The suspect was initially identified to be Min Yingjun ({{zh|s=闵应军 |t=閔應軍 |p=Mǐn Yìngjūn}}); however, later reports identified the perpetrator to be a different man, Min Yongjun ({{zh|s=闵拥军 |t=閔擁軍 |p=Mǐn Yōngjūn |links=no}}), of the same village as Min Yingjun.[http://money.jrj.com.cn/2012/12/17093614829777.shtml 闵应军：河南22名学生被砍 凶犯闵应军实为"闵拥军" ] He is reported to have had a long history of [[epileptic seizures]], and to have been influenced by the [[2012 phenomenon|2012 doomsday phenomenon]]. This has recently been propagated in China by the [[Oriental Lightning]] cult.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/17/us-china-doomsday-idUSBRE8BG0ES20121217|title=China detains 93 for doomsday rumors: Xinhua|first=Sui-Lee|last=Wee|editor1-first=Robert|editor1-last=Birsel|agency=Reuters|date=2012-12-17|accessdate=2012-12-17}} ==Response== The [[Guangshan County]] government established an emergency response team for the incident. The coverage of the incident in local media was tightly controlled, with Beijing usually restricting coverage of such sensitive topics to dissuade copycat attacks, and an article in the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported a backlash by Chinese citizens due to the lack of coverage of the school stabbings. An article in [[The Associated Press]] similarly wrote that a possible reason why authorities wanted to restrict the news was to either "prevent encouraging others or to play down the crime to keep blame off the government." Officials detained 52 people for spreading doomsday rumours, such as distributing leaflets.{{cite news | url = http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/?id=519288&type=National | title = School hacker obsessed with doomsday | date = 17 December 2012 | author = Li Qian | publisher = [[Shanghai Daily]] }} On 16 December, the suspect was arrested and charged with the crime of endangering public safety by dangerous means.[http://www.cpd.com.cn/n10216060/n10216148/c15116724/content.html 河南光山砍伤学生嫌疑人闵拥军被批准逮捕], cpd.com.cn Six officials were fired. The reason for the dismissals have not been announced.{{cite news | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-wires/20121218/as-china-school-stabbing/ | title = 6 Chinese officials fired after school stabbing | agency = Associated Press | publisher = The Huffington Post | date = 18 December 2012 }} ==Reactions== Some commentaries situated the knife attacks in the wider context of China's social and economic transformation, noting the inadequacies in the country’s health care system for diagnosing and treating citizens suffering psychiatric distress and illnesses.{{cite news| last= Liu| first= Melinda| title=Not Just Sandy Hook: China’s Terrifying Knife Attacks| url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/12/15/not-just-sandy-hook-china-s-terrifying-knife-attacks.html| newspaper=The Daily Beast| date=15 December 2012}} As the Chenpeng school attack was followed by the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]] in the United States hours later{{cite news|url=http://www.china-xian.com/sh/fzsh/201212/1534635.htm |script-title=zh:闵拥军砍伤22名学生 中国36岁男子闵拥军落网 - 名城西安 |publisher=China-xian.com |date=15 December 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2012 |language=Chinese}}{{cite web| url= http://americanlivewire.com/22-students-in-china-stabbed-in-elementary-school-attack-by-36-year-old-villager-min-yingjun/ |title=22 Students In China Stabbed In Elementary School Attack by 36-year-old Villager Min Yongjun |publisher=American Live Wire |accessdate=15 December 2012}} comparisons were drawn between the two. The difference in gun control laws between the two countries was used to explain the disparity in casualties of the school attacks by journalists and politicians, including U.S. Representative [[Jerrold Nadler|Jerry Nadler]],{{cite journal | url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/evanosnos/2012/12/china-watches-newtown-guns-american-credibility.html | title = China Watches Newtown: Guns and American Credibility | author = Evan Osnos |authorlink = Evan Osnos| magazine = [[The New Yorker]] | date = 15 December 2012 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/15/gun-control-jerry-nadler_n_2307340.html | first= Michael |last= McAuliff | title = On Gun Control, Jerry Nadler Explains What Congress Could Do Right Now | date = 15 December 2012 | work = [[The Huffington Post]] }} and an article in the [[Associated Press]] noted that despite the different outcomes, an underlying commonality between the attacks was the increased frequency of school attacks because, "attackers often seek out the vulnerable, hoping to amplify their outrage before they themselves often commit suicide."{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5izvHNVyzzEe08iLX7PD_jXND3pvQ?docId=031a85c4f4064ac59a3d2575d09e4bfe |title=Schools and students are targets worldwide |first= Charles |last= Hutzler |agency=Associated Press |date=15 December 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2012}} Comparisons were also drawn between the incident handling by the local and national governments involved. The lack of coverage by Chinese state-run news channels, and the lack of any emotional response from the Chinese government at all levels were contrasted to the detailed US media coverage and US President [[Barack Obama]]'s national speech, including his commitment to tackle the underlying issues.{{cite news | url = http://ibnlive.in.com/news/china-highlights-contrasting-gun-law/310895-70.html | title = China highlights contrasting gun law | author = Jamil Anderlini | agency = [[Financial Times]] | publisher = [[CNN-IBN]] | date = 16 December 2012 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2248054/China-stabbing-22-children-elderly-woman-stabbed-outside-primary-school-Chinese-knifeman.html | title = 22 children and elderly woman stabbed outside primary school by Chinese knifeman | work= [[Daily Mail]] | first= Phil |last= Vinter | date = 14 December 2012 | location=London}}{{citation | url=http://www.morningwhistle.com/html/2012/PoliticsSociety_1217/216109.html | date=17 December 2012 | author= Xu Weiwei | title= Knife attack on school injures 23 kids in China | work=Morning Whistle | accessdate= 18 December 2012}} ==Footage== The local police released footage from a security camera showing the attacker barging into the school and attacking a student. The video was noted and analysed by many news agencies, and contributed significantly to the widespread coverage of the incident.{{cite news|title=Chinese Police Release Video of School Stabbing|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/chinese-police-release-video-school-stabbing-18013111#.UNNAyW_AdNM|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=AP|date=19 December 2012}}{{cite news|title=WATCH: Shocking video of stabbing spree at Chinese school|url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/WOR-TOP-watch-shocking-video-of-stabbing-spree-at-chinese-school-4119067-NOR.html|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=Daily Bhaskar|date=20 December 2012}} ==See also== * [[List of attacks related to primary schools]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Portal bar|2010s|China|Criminal justice|Schools}} [[Category:2012 crimes in China]] [[Category:Attacks on schools]] [[Category:Crime in China]] [[Category:Crimes against children]] [[Category:Primary schools in China]] [[Category:History of Henan]] [[Category:Mass stabbings]] [[Category:Xinyang]] [[Category:School killings in China]] [[Category:Knife attacks]] [[Category:December 2012 crimes]]

{{Infobox play | name = Christmas Goose With Quince | image = | image_size = 225px | caption = | writer = [[Miho Mosulishvili]] | genre = [[Comedy-Thriller]] | setting = 21st-century Europe | subject = Bonifacius, Michael Danser, Helen Quince, Carlo, Rosalia, Horse from the TV | premiere = December 25, 2009 | place = Iliauni Theatre, Tbilisi (Georgia) | orig_lang = Georgian }} '''''Christmas Goose With Quince''''' (Comic thriller in one act)<ref>{{Citation|publisher = Saari|publication-place = Tbilisi, Georgia|author = Mixo Mosulišvili|url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL24988611M/Titqmis_picaso_da_cota_boskhi_marjvnidan|title = Titqmis picaso da cota boskhi, marjvnidan|publication-date = 2010}}</ref> is a 2012 play by [[Georgian people|Georgian]] [[playwright]] [[Miho Mosulishvili]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kkpress.ge/index.php?do=fullmod/news&id=1087&mid=4|title="ბატი კომშით"-პრემიერა რუსთავის დრამატულ თეატრში|publisher=kkpress.ge|language=Georgian|accessdate=8 March 2014}}</ref>
==Plot synopsis== In one ordinary, but got to a big debt, a family of Newlyweds (the husband Michael Danser and the wife Helen Quince) were very lucky, to them the owner of that consortium (Bonifacius) where they work with indecent desire goes the guest for a congratulation of Christmas.
Because of offered a large number of money a young married couple is compelled to serve and will execute all humiliating requirements from his strange guest, the owner of consortium, Gabriel Bonifacius, then because of it when Helen and Michael feel torment oneself, Newlyweds kill Bonifatius.
At this time to newlyweds come Michael's parents, Carlo and Rosalia for a congratulation Christmas too.
When they learn that newlyweds killed Bonifatius, at first they want to hide Helen and Michael, but then start thinking about own wellbeing and begin calls in police. But as it becomes clear, the visitor of consortium didn't die, it we live also healthy leaves the refrigerator where murderers hid his sawn parts of a body. It appears that Bonifatius not the person, but it is an angel who asks everything what sometimes to reflect that we do.
==Characters== * '''Bonifacius''' - The owner Bonfatius consortium; it is difficult to guess, how old is he * '''Michael Danser''' - The designer in Bonifatius's consortium, but a painter, age 32 * '''Helen Quince''' - The manager of marketing in Bonfatius's consortium, age 30 * '''Carlo''' - Michael's father, age 63 * '''Rosalia''' - Michael's mother, age 60 * '''Horse from the TV''' - The horse a racer, age 3
==Production== * December 25, 2009 - Iliauni Theatre, Tbilisi, director Guram Bregadze * June 21, 2013 - Rustavi Drama Theatre (Georgia), director Guram Bregadze, choreographer George Margania, designer Lomgul Murusidze
==Publication== * Mikho Mosulishvili: ''Almost Picasso and on a few Bosch, on the right side (Seven Plays)'' (Originaltitel: ''თითქმის პიკასო და ცოტა ბოსხი, მარჯვნიდან'').<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/titkmis-pikaso-da-cota-bosxi-marjvnidan-svidi-piesa/oclc/862752450 Tʻitʻkʻmis Pikaso da cʻota Bosxi marjvnidan : (s̆vidi piesa)]</ref> * "Weihnachtsgans mit Quitten" von Micho Mosulischwili im buch: "Zwischen Orient und Okzident" (Theaterstücke aus Georgien),<ref>[http://www.theaterderzeit.de/buch/zwischen_orient_und_okzident/ Zwischen Orient und Okzident (Theaterstücke aus Georgien)]</ref> Verlag Theater der Zeit, 2015, {{ISBN|978-3-95749-061-2}}
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsM/mosulishvili-mikho.html MIKHO MOSULISHVILI (1962 - )] * [https://openlibrary.org/works/OL16092374W/Titqmis_picaso_da_cota_boskhi_marjvnidan Almost Picasso and on a few Bosch, on the right side]
{{Miho Mosulishvili}}

{{Cleanup|reason=exhaustive lists|date=July 2015}} The '''Computers, Freedom and Privacy Conference''' (or '''CFP''', or the '''Conference on Computers, Freedom and Privacy''') is an annual [[academic conference]] held in the United States or Canada about the intersection of [[computer]] technology, [[Freedom (political)|freedom]], and [[privacy]] issues. The conference was founded in 1991,<ref name=McCullagh99a /> and since at least 1999,<ref name=Seminerio99a /> it has been organized under the aegis of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]]. It was originally sponsored by [[Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility|CPSR]].
== CFP91 == The first CFP was held in 1991 in Burlingame, California. <ref name=McCullagh99a />
== CFP99 ==
The Computers, Freedom and Privacy 99 Conference, sponsored by the [[Association for Computing Machinery]], <ref name=Seminerio99a>{{cite news |title=New cyber privacy policy has powerful support |first1=Maria |last1=Seminerio |work=PC Week |date=6 Apr 1999 |url=http://www.zdnet.com/pcweek/stories/news/0,4153,1014290,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508091852/http://www.zdnet.com/pcweek/stories/news/0%2C4153%2C1014290%2C00.html |archivedate=8 May 1999 |accessdate=24 Jul 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> the 9th annual CFP, was held in Washington, DC from 6 April 1999 to 8 April 1999. <ref name=Roberts99>{{cite news |title=Conference on Computers, Freedom + Privacy |first1=Sue Ann |last1=Roberts |work=ZDTV |date=6 Apr 1999 |url=http://www.zdnet.com/zdtv/cybercrime/features/story/0,3700,2235576,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990507235123/http://www.zdnet.com/zdtv/cybercrime/features/story/0%2C3700%2C2235576%2C00.html |archivedate=7 May 1999 |accessdate=24 Jul 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> CFP99 focused on international Internet regulation and privacy protection. <ref name=McCullagh99a>{{cite news|title= Shaping Online Privacy |first1=Declan|last1=McCullagh |work=Wired News|date=6 Apr 1999 |url=https://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/18969.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508230612/http://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/18969.html |archivedate=8 May 1999 |accessdate=24 Jul 2014}}</ref> There were close to 500 registered participants and attendees included high-level government officials, grassroots advocates and programmers. <ref name=Macavinta99c>{{cite news |title=U.S. privacy policy trailing behind |first1=Courtney |last1=Macavinta |work=CNET News.com, 9 April 1999 |url=http://www.news.com/News/Item/0,4,34869,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508045740/http://www.news.com/News/Item/0%2C4%2C34869%2C00.html |archivedate=8 May 1999 |accessdate=26 Jul 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The conference chair for CFP99 was [[Marc Rotenberg]] and the program coordinator was Ross Stapleton-Gray. <ref name=McCullagh99a />
Keynote speakers at CFP99 were [[Tim Berners-Lee]], director of the [[World Wide Web Consortium]],<ref name=Roberts99 /> [[Vint Cerf]], president of the [[Internet Society]] <ref name=Roberts99 /> <ref name=Clausing99b>{{cite news|title= Congress Returns to a Flurry of Technology Legislation |first1=Jeri|last1=Clausing |work=The New York Times|date=13 April 1999 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/tech/99/04/cyber/articles/13capital.html |accessdate=26 Jul 2014}}</ref> and [[Federal Trade Commission|FTC]] Commissioner Mozelle Thompson. <ref name=Roberts99 />
Others who spoke at CFP99 included: David Banisar, policy director at the [[Electronic Privacy Information Center]];<ref name=Clausing99b /><ref name=Lewis99>{{cite news|title=Internet Hide and Seek: Staying Under Cover|first1=Peter H.|last1=Lewis|work=The New York Times|date=8 April 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/tech/99/04/circuits/articles/08pete.html|accessdate=26 Jul 2014}}</ref> US Representative [[Bob Barr]] former federal prosecutor and Georgia Republican;<ref name=McCullagh99b>{{cite news|title=Big Brother Taps the Bitstream|first1=Declan|last1=McCullagh|work=Wired News|date=7 April 1999|url=https://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/18987.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508233634/http://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/18987.html|archivedate=8 May 1999|accessdate=24 Jul 2014}}</ref><ref name=Macavinta99b>{{cite news|title=Conference monitors privacy concerns|first1=Courtney|last1=Macavinta|work=CNET News.com|date=7 April 1999|url=http://www.news.com/News/Item/0,4,34750,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508163821/http://www.news.com/News/Item/0%2C4%2C34750%2C00.html|archivedate=8 May 1999|accessdate=24 Jul 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Colin Bennett, a privacy expert at Canada's [[University of Victoria]];<ref name=Macavinta99c /> Paula Breuning, a lawyer for the [[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]] in the [[United States Department of Commerce]];<ref name=Macavinta99b /><ref name=Johnston99a /><ref name=Johnston99c>{{cite news|title=Privacy advocate vows to 'ratchet up' Internet fight|first1=Margret|last1=Johnston|work=ComputerWorld|date=7 April 1999|url=http://www.computerworld.com/home/news.nsf/all/9904073priv|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990507235610/http://www.computerworld.com/home/news.nsf/all/9904073priv|archivedate=7 May 1999|accessdate=24 Jul 2014}}</ref> Becky Burr, head of the Commerce Department unit overseeing many Internet issues;<ref name=Pressman99>{{cite news|title=Self-regulation still alive and well?|first1=Aaron|last1=Pressman|agency=Reuters|work=ZD Net News|date=8 April 1999|url=http://www.zdnet.com/zdnn/stories/news/0,4586,2239153,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000815094437/http://www.zdnet.com/zdnn/stories/news/0%2C4586%2C2239153%2C00.html|archivedate=2000-08-15|accessdate=26 Jul 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Jason Catlett, privacy advocate and president of [[Internet Junkbuster|JunkBusters]];<ref name=Clausing99b /><ref name=Pressman99 /> Scott Charney, head of the [[United States Department of Justice]] computer crimes unit;<ref name=McCullagh99b /><ref name=Macavinta99b /> the artist Henry Cross;<ref name=McCullagh99d>{{cite news|title=MP3 Foes Cussing Out in DC|first1=Declan|last1=McCullagh|work=Wired News|date=8 April 1999|url=https://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/19007.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991130072954/http://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/19007.html|archivedate=30 November 1999|accessdate=26 Jul 2014}}</ref> [[Simon Davies (privacy advocate)|Simon Davies]], Fellow of the [[London School of Economics]] and representative of [[Privacy International]];<ref name=Johnston99a /><ref name=Johnston99c /> [[Elizabeth France]], head of the UK [[Data Protection Registrar]];<ref name=Macavinta99c /> Bob Gellman, privacy consultant;<ref name=Macavinta99c /> Peter Hustinx, president of the Dutch Data Protection Authority;<ref name=Macavinta99c /> Stephen Lau Ka-men, [[Hong Kong]]'s Privacy Commissioner for Personal Data;<ref name=Macavinta99b /><ref name=Macavinta99a>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong privacy chief blasts U.S. policy|first1=Courtney|last1=Macavinta|work=CNET News.com|date=7 April 1999|url=http://news.cnet.com/news/0-1005-200-340879.html?tag=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000816025451/http://news.cnet.com/news/0-1005-200-340879.html?tag=|archivedate=16 August 2000|accessdate=24 Jul 2014}}</ref> Jim Lewis from the [[US Commerce Department]]'s [[Bureau of Export Administration]];<ref name=McCullagh99e>{{cite news|title=Crypto Cabal: Make Code Not Guns|first1=Declan|last1=McCullagh|work=Wired News|date=8 April 1999|url=https://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/19018.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991130081911/http://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/19018.html|archivedate=30 November 1999|accessdate=26 Jul 2014}}</ref> US Representative [[Ed Markey]], a ranking Democrat on the House Subcommittee for Telecommunications, Trade and Consumer Protection;<ref name=McCullagh99d /><ref name=Boodhoo99b>{{cite news|title=U.S. Rep Wants Online Privacy Bill|first1=Niala|last1=Boodhoo|work=PC World|date=7 April 1999|url=http://www2.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0,1510,10430,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990921144828/http://www2.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0%2C1510%2C10430%2C00.html|archivedate=1999-09-21|accessdate=24 Jul 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=Johnston99b>{{cite news|title=U.S. lawmaker to propose Net privacy bill|first1=Margret|last1=Johnston|work=InfoWorld Electric|date=7 April 1999|url=http://www.infoworld.com/cgi-bin/displayStory.pl?99047.eiprivacy.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990828214118/http://www.infoworld.com/cgi-bin/displayStory.pl?99047.eiprivacy.htm|archivedate=28 August 1999|accessdate=24 Jul 2014}}</ref><ref name=Harrison99>{{cite news|title=Privacy protection tools gain support at confab|first1=Ann|last1=Harrison|work=Computerworld, 12 April 1999|url=http://www.computerworld.com/home/print.nsf/all/9904129E46|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991011062434/http://www.computerworld.com/home/print.nsf/all/9904129E46|archivedate=11 October 1999|accessdate=25 Jul 2014}}</ref><ref name=Clausing99a>{{cite news|title=Lawmaker Plans Bill to Protect Consumer Privacy Online|first1=Jeri|last1=Clausing|work=The New York|date=8 April 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/tech/99/04/cyber/articles/08privacy.html|accessdate=25 Jul 2014}}</ref> Erich Moechel from [[Quintessenz]], Austria;<ref name=McCullagh99b /> [[Aryeh Neier]], president of the [[Open Society Institute]];<ref name=Johnston99c /> Jagdesh Parikh, an official with [[Human Rights Watch]];<ref name=Seminerio99b>{{cite news|title=Free speech and privacy forever linked|first1=Maria|last1=Seminerio|work=ZDNet News|date=8 April 1999|url=http://www.zdnet.com/zdnn/stories/news/0,4586,2238527,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000815094432/http://www.zdnet.com/zdnn/stories/news/0%2C4586%2C2238527%2C00.html|archivedate=2000-08-15|accessdate=25 Jul 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> [[Philip Reitinger]], a prosecutor for the [[US Justice Department]];<ref name=Lewis99 /> Carol Risher, vice president of the [[American Association of Publishers]];<ref name=McCullagh99d /> [[Michael Robertson (businessman)|Michael Robertson]], president of [[MP3.com]];<ref name=McCullagh99d /> Cary Scherman, general counsel of the [[Recording Industry Association of America]];<ref name=McCullagh99d /> [[Bruce Schneier]], president of [[Counterpane Internet Security|Counterpane Systems]];<ref name=McCullagh99e /> [[Barbara Simons]], president of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]];<ref name=Macavinta99b /> David Sobel, legal counsel at the [[Electronic Privacy Information Center]];<ref name=Seminerio99b /> [[Latanya Sweeney]], Assistant Professor of Computer Science, Technology and Policy at [[Carnegie Mellon University]];<ref name=Seminerio99b /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sweeney|first1=Latanya|title=Biographical sketch of Latanya Sweeney, Ph.D.|url=http://lab.privacy.cs.cmu.edu/people/sweeney/bioprivacy.html|accessdate=26 Jul 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030904135835/http://lab.privacy.cs.cmu.edu/people/sweeney/bioprivacy.html|archivedate=4 September 2003}}</ref> [[Peter Swire]], chief counselor for privacy in the US [[Office of Management and Budget]];<ref name=Macavinta99c /> Greg Taylor of [[Electronic Frontiers Australia]];<ref name=McCullagh99a /> [[Christine Varney]], representative of the [[Online Privacy Alliance]] and former [[Federal Trade Commission|FTC]] commissioner;<ref name=Macavinta99c /> George Vrandenburg, senior vice president of [[America Online]];<ref name=Johnston99c /> Steve Wright, of the UK-based nonprofit Omega Foundation, author of a report on [[ECHELON]];<ref name=McCullagh99b /><ref name=Macavinta99b />
Discussion Panels at CFP99 included: Anonymity and Identity in Cyberspace;<ref name=Roberts99 /> Creation of a Global Surveillance Network;<ref name=Roberts99 /><ref name=Macavinta99b /> Global Internet Censorship;<ref name=McCullagh99a /> Privacy;<ref name=Johnston99a>{{cite news|title=Take Net Privacy Into Your Own Hands|first1=Margret|last1=Johnston|work=PC World|date=7 April 1999|url=http://www.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0,1510,10422,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508031215/http://www.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0%2C1510%2C10422%2C00.html|archivedate=8 May 1999|accessdate=24 Jul 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=Johnston99c /> Privacy and data protection policies;<ref name=Macavinta99c /> Self Regulation Reconsidered.<ref name=Roberts99 /><ref name=Johnston99c />
Topics covered at CFP99 included: Anonymity;<ref name=Lewis99 /> Protection of <!-- Children -->children by parents and teachers, not government;<ref name=Boodhoo99a>{{cite news|title=Internet Pioneer Urges Unfettered Net|first1=Niala|last1=Boodhoo|work=PC World|date=7 April 1999|url=http://www.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0,1510,10433,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508042512/http://www.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0%2C1510%2C10433%2C00.html|archivedate=8 May 1999|accessdate=24 Jul 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Fair use of <!-- Copyright, Fair use -->copyrighted material;<ref name=Macavinta99b /> Controls over the <!-- Cryptography -->[[export of cryptography]] under the [[Wassenaar Arrangement]];<ref name=McCullagh99e /> Data mining and identity theft;<ref name=Seminerio99b /> Encryption;<ref name=Macavinta99b /> Free speech;<ref name=Macavinta99b /> Government disclosure;<ref name=Macavinta99b /> Human rights;<ref name=Macavinta99b /> The <!-- Link -->link between privacy and free speech;<ref name=Seminerio99b /> Discussion between <!-- MP3 -->[[MP3]] activists, musicians and the recording industry;<ref name=McCullagh99d /> Privacy and data protection by self-regulation or legislation?;<ref name=Pressman99 /> Proposed <!-- privacy legislation -->privacy legislation;<ref name=McCullagh99d /> Self-regulation of online privacy;<ref name=Clausing99a /> Whether the Internet would remain <!-- Unfettered -->"unfettered and unregulated";<ref name=Clausing99a />
=== Awards at CFP99 === The first annual [[Big Brother Awards (United States)|US Big Brother Awards]] were made at CFP99 on Wednesday 7 April 1999,<ref name=McCullagh99a /> the 50th aniversiary of the publication of George Orwell's [[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]. The awards were made by the London-based [[Privacy International]] to recognize "the government and private sector organizations which have done the most to invade personal privacy in the United States." <ref name=Diederich99>{{cite news|title= Intel, US Govt "honored" for breaches of privacy |first1=Tom|last1=Diederich |work=Computerworld|date=8 April 1999 |url=http://linuxworld.com/linuxworld/lw-1999-04/lw-04-orwell.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991004233003/http://linuxworld.com/linuxworld/lw-1999-04/lw-04-orwell.html |archivedate=4 October 1999 |accessdate=25 Jul 2014}}</ref> [[Simon Davies (privacy advocate)|Simon Davies]], managing director of Privacy International, presented the awards, otherwise known as Orwells. There were five categories of award: Greatest Corporate Invader, Lifetime Menace, Most Invasive Program, People's Choice, and Worst Public Official. <ref name=Boodhoo99c>{{cite news |title=Orwell's Legacy: Big Brother Awards |first1=Niala |last1=Boodhoo |work=PC World |date=8 April 1999 |url=http://www.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0,1510,10441,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508055915/http://www.pcworld.com/pcwtoday/article/0%2C1510%2C10441%2C00.html |archivedate=8 May 1999 |accessdate=25 Jul 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
At CFP99 [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] made the 1999 [[EFF Pioneer Award]]s to Drazen Pantic, Director of OpenNet, Internet provider to Belgrade radio station [[B92#B92.net (ex OpenNet)|B92]]; posthumously to Jon Postel, who ran the [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]]; and [[Simon Davies (privacy advocate)|Simon Davies]], director of [[Privacy International]]. <ref name=McCullagh99c>{{cite news|title= Yugoslav Dissident Lauded |first1=Declan|last1=McCullagh |work=Wired News|date=7 April 1999 |url=https://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/18990.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991128111457/https://www.wired.com/news/news/politics/story/18990.html |archivedate=28 November 1999 |accessdate=24 Jul 2014}}</ref>
=== Announcements at CFP99 ===
US Representative Edward Markey, (D-Massachusetts) said that to ensure companies post clear and enforcable privacy policies, federal legislation is required,<ref name=Harrison99 /> and that he would re-introduce a privacy bill of rights.<ref name=Boodhoo99b /><ref name=Johnston99b /><ref name=Clausing99a />
At CFP99 [[Microsoft]],<ref name=Harrison99 /><ref name=Clausing99a /> the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] <ref name=Clausing99a /> and [[TRUSTe|Truste]] <ref name=Harrison99 /> announced that they had developed a "Privacy Wizard" to assist webmasters create a [[P3P|Privacy Preferences Project]] statement for their websites.<ref name=Harrison99 /><ref name=Clausing99a />
== CFP2000 ==
The CFP2000 conference chair was [[Lorrie Faith Cranor]]. <ref name=Roberts99 />
== CFP2005 == {{primary sources|section on CFP2005|date=July 2014}} The fifteenth iteration of the conference was held in Seattle. The theme of this conference was [[equiveillance]], the balance between [[surveillance]] and [[sousveillance]]. The equiveillance theme was reflected in the Opening Keynote Address, a panel discussion on equiveillance, and a pre-keynote sousveillance workshop, as well as a sousveillance performance.<ref>http://wearcam.org/cfp2005/</ref> In keeping with this theme, every conference attendee received a sousveillance system consisting of a "maybecamera" attached to each conference bag. Some of the 500 conference bags contained cameras transmitting live 24/7 video whereas others contained no camera, but merely the familiar camera dome. A third category of conference bag included some with a subtle but visible flashing red light behind the dome. Not all of the wireless web cameras had flashing red lights, and some of the flashing red lights were dummy devices that did not transmit video. The bags that did transmit video also updated various video displays around the conference hall, visible to conference attendees.
== CFP2009 == [[File:Susan Crawford speaking at Computers Freedom and Privacy Conference 2009.jpg|thumb|left|[[Susan P. Crawford]] speaking at CFP 2009.]]
== CFP2011 == {{primary sources|section on CFP2011|date=July 2014}} The twenty-first annual CFP Conference in 2011, "Computers, Freedom, and Privacy: The Future is Now", was held at the Georgetown Law Center in Washington, DC June 14–16. Among the questions and issues explored were: What is social media’s role in the charged democracy movement in the Middle East and North Africa; How can technology and social media support human rights, What is the impact of mobile personal computing technology on freedom and privacy? Are the courts, policy and decision makers ready to address freedom and privacy in a 24-7 connected world? Are our leaders techs savvy enough to make good legal and policy decisions regarding the deployment of [[smart grid]], e-health records, the spread of consumer location based advertising? Cybersecurity, cloud computing, net neutrality, federated ID, ubiquitous surveillance: Are they passing fads or here to stay? <ref>http://www.cfp.org/2011/wiki/index.php/Main_Page</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://www.cfp.org/ Official site]

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
'''Darius McCollum''' (born March 28th 1965)[https://www.freedariusnow.com/darius-mccollum/] is primarily known for posing as [[New York City Subway]] [[motorman]] and bus driver and operating subway trains and buses for [[Joyride (crime)|joyrides]]. McCollum is a [[New York City]] resident with a lengthy arrest record for crimes related to the transit system operated by the [[New York City]] [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] (MTA). He has been fascinated with trains since his childhood, and has been diagnosed with [[Asperger syndrome]].
==Characteristics==
McCollum has been interested in trains from an early age, frequently riding the [[New York City Subway|New York Subway]] for days at a time. His fixation with trains has led McCollum to frequently impersonate MTA employees or a related entity, for which he has been jailed numerous times. McCollum has been rejected for employment by MTA on numerous occasions, although he is reported to know more about the trains, schedules, procedures and rail operations than any current employee.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Orphan Diseases: New Hope for Rare Medical Conditions |author=Murphy, Wendy B |year=2002 |publisher=Twenty-First Century Books |isbn=0-7613-1919-0}}</ref>
A prison psychiatrist who did an evaluation diagnosed him with [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref name="Tietz">{{Cite news|first=Jeff |last=Tietz |title=The boy who loved transit: how the system failed an obsession |url=http://www.findarticles.com/cf_0/m1111/1824_304/85882845/print.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030927155810/http://www.findarticles.com/cf_0/m1111/1824_304/85882845/print.jhtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2003-09-27 |work=[[Harper's Magazine]] |publisher=Gale Group |date=May 2002 |accessdate=2007-11-08 }}</ref> McCollum is said to have memorized the [[New York City Subway map]] by age 8.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2015/11/11/darius-mccollum-greyhound-bus/|title=Man Known For Posing As Transit Worker Steals Greyhound Bus: Cops « CBS New York|work=cbslocal.com|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref>
==Notable arrests==
According to McCollum's mother, his interest with the [[New York City Subway]] system started in his youth, when subway motormen permitted him to drive trains.<ref name="Donohue Moore 2013"/> McCollum was first arrested in 1980,<ref>{{cite web | title=Top 10 Imposters | website=TIME.com | date=2009-05-26 | url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1900621_1900618_1900590,00.html | accessdate=2015-11-16}}</ref> at age 15, when he drove an in-service New York City Subway [[E (New York City Subway service)|E train]] for six stops.<ref name="Donohue Moore 2013">{{cite web | last=Donohue | first=Pete | last2=Moore | first2=Tina | title=Transit bus thief released from prison after 2010 swipe | website=NY Daily News | date=2013-12-25 | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/nyc-crime/transit-thief-released-prison-lock-trains-buses-article-1.1557950 | accessdate=2015-11-16}}</ref> While he was in jail at [[Rikers Island]], he wrote to the [[New York City Department of Correction]] and asked if he could drive one of their buses.<ref name="Donohue Moore 2013"/> By the mid-1990s, McCollum "had become a minor cult figure", particularly after the MTA posted thousands of [[wanted poster]]s in trains and stations so that riders could report sightings. Occasionally, McCollum would appear as transit employees named "Morning" or "Manning", who riders invariably experienced as friendly and helpful.<ref name="Osborne">{{Cite book|title=American Normal: The Hidden World of Asperger Syndrome|author=Osborne, Lawrence|first=|publisher=Copernicus|year=2002|isbn=0-387-95307-8|location=|pages=3}}</ref>
By 2000, McCollum had been jailed 19 times for transit-related crimes. That year he pleaded guilty to charges of forgery and burglary for signing out a train according to proper MTA procedure to perform customary duties (extinguishing track fires, supervising maintenance), and then signing it back in. He was sentenced to a minimum of {{frac|2|1|2}} to 5 years in prison.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/30/nyregion/judge-clearly-not-amused-sentences-a-subway-impostor.html |title=Judge, Clearly Not Amused, Sentences... |date=March 31, 2001 |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=2009-08-01 |first=Dean E. |last=Murphy}}</ref> In 2005, McCollum was apprehended at a [[Long Island Rail Road]] yard with the keys to an [[M-7 (railcar)|M-7 railcar]] in his pocket. They had been given to him by his MTA friends who had given him their shifts, but he pleaded guilty to attempting to steal a locomotive and was sentenced to three years in prison.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.queensda.org/Press%20Releases/2005%20Press%20Releases/04-April/04-06-2005.htm |title=Darius McCollum sentencing release |date=April 6, 2005 |publisher=[[Queens]] District Attorney's Office |accessdate=2007-11-07}}</ref> Although he was released from [[Sing Sing]] in 2006, he was reimprisoned for breaking parole after he was found in possession of railroad property.<ref name="Landry, Bernice">{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/ideas/media/2008/dark-end-of-the-spectrum-episode-2.ram |title=CBC Ideas: The Dark End of The Spectrum, Part II |author=Landry, Bernice |date=July 31, 2009 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] |accessdate=2009-08-01}}</ref>
On June 13, 2008, McCollum, now 43, was arrested again. He was wearing a hardhat and carrying a knapsack, flashlight and gloves with an MTA logo. He was dressed in the blue T-shirt and work pants typically worn by track workers and was arrested as he tried to enter a restricted area of a midtown station.<ref name=nyd20080614/><ref name=nyt20080614/> McCollum was charged with criminal impersonation, criminal trespass and possession of burglary tools—a hammer and screwdriver tucked in his backpack. These "burglary tools" are also the typical repair equipment that all MTA maintenance workers carry.<ref name=nyd20080614/><ref name=nyt20080614/> When his mother was interviewed over the telephone, she said, "Any time Darius wears anything remotely resembling the transit uniform, he gets arrested."<ref name=nyd20080614>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2008/06/14/2008-06-14_citys_great_train_robber_at_it_again_ser.html |title="City's great train robber at it again: Serial subway imposter caught," New York Daily News, June 14, 2008 |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-24}}</ref><ref name=nyt20080614>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/15/nyregion/15arrest.html?_r=1&oref=slogin |title="Queens Man Obsessed With Trains Is Arrested Again," New York Times, June 15, 2008 |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2008-06-15 |accessdate=2013-07-24}}</ref>
McCollum was released from the [[Downstate Correctional Facility]] on July 3, 2007—nine months after his arrest for violating parole by returning to the city from [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina|Winston-Salem]], [[North Carolina]].<ref name=nyd20080614/><ref name=nyt20080614/> He was arrested at [[Pennsylvania Station (New York City)|Penn Station]] on October 5, 2008, for impersonating a [[Long Island Rail Road]] employee and answering passengers' questions.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2008/10/06/2008-10-06_railroad_buff_derailed_again_26th_bust_f.html |title=Railroad buff derailed again, 26th bust for man cops say impersonated fed |author=Donohue, Pete |work=New York Daily News |date=October 6, 2008 |accessdate=October 7, 2008}}</ref>
On August 31, 2010, McCollum was arrested for the 27th time and charged with grand larceny and possession of stolen property in connection with the theft of a private bus from a [[Trailways of New York]] terminal in [[Hoboken, New Jersey]]<ref name=nyp20100831>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/subway_car_stealer_busted_for_stealing_cz8BCyoV04Ai8fdnMfyF5L |title=Transit bandit busted for stealing bus, cuffed carrying Koran |author=Cartwright, Lachlan |work=New York Post |date=August 31, 2010 |accessdate=September 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905005607/http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/subway_car_stealer_busted_for_stealing_cz8BCyoV04Ai8fdnMfyF5L |archivedate=September 5, 2010 |df= }}</ref> According to police, McCollum allegedly boarded the bus at approximately 6:30 a.m. that morning and discovered the keys left in the ignition. McCollum is accused of then commandeering the bus, with the theft reportedly going unnoticed for two hours as McCollum drove around [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]] and [[Jamaica, Queens]]. McCollum was taken into custody without incident. Police stated McCollum is "very smart, he's not a dumb guy" and that he was a "gentleman" during arrest and processing.<ref name=nyp20100831/><ref name=g20100831/> At the time of his arrest, he had spent 18 years—more than a third of his life—in jail for transit-related offenses.<ref name=g20100831>{{cite web |author=Ben Yakas |url=http://gothamist.com/2010/08/31/1_subway_superfan_darius_mccollum_a.php |title=#1 Subway Superfan Darius McCollum Arrested For Stealing Bus |publisher=Gothamist |date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2013-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231030014/http://gothamist.com/2010/08/31/1_subway_superfan_darius_mccollum_a.php |archivedate=2013-12-31 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Donohue Moore 2013"/> In 2013, McCollum pleaded guilty to stealing the Trailways bus. On December 24 of that year, McCollum was released on [[parole]] and was to voluntarily enter [[cognitive behavioral therapy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/nyc-transit-impostor-released-jail-21334798|title=U.S. News - National News|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> The terms of the parole, which lasted until August 24, 2015, required that he does not operate a motor vehicle.<ref name="Donohue Moore 2013"/>
On November 11, 2015, McCollum was arrested for stealing a Greyhound bus from the [[Port Authority Bus Terminal]] in [[Manhattan]]. He drove the [[GPS]]-equipped bus for approximately 2 hours until his arrest at approximately 4 p.m. in [[Gowanus, Brooklyn]]. According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', McCollum said, “I’m stealing a plane next” after his arrest.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rojas |first1=Rick |title=Repeat Train Thief Steals Bus at Port Authority, Police Say |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/12/nyregion/repeat-train-thief-steals-bus-at-port-authority-police-say.html?ref=nyregion&_r=0 |accessdate=12 November 2015 |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times |date=11 November 2015}}</ref>
Although his parents, who moved to Winston-Salem, North Carolina, believe McCollum should leave New York to avoid the temptation of the trains,<ref name="Haberman">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/12/nyregion/12nyc.html?_r=1&oref=slogin |title=Back in Prison, Guilty Mainly of a Fixation |author=Haberman, Clyde |date=April 12, 2005 |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=2007-11-07}}</ref> parole conditions have until recently repeatedly restricted McCollum to remain in New York City.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article382503.ece |title=On the wrong track |author=Knight, Sam |date=April 18, 2005 |publisher=The Times |accessdate=2007-11-07 |location=London}}</ref> Suggestions from his parents and [[autism]] advocates that the MTA find a way to hire McCollum in some capacity, in the manner of [[Frank Abagnale]], are rejected by transit officials, who fear legal liability and anti-disability stigma.<ref name="Haberman"/> In January 2018, McCollum took a [[plea bargain]] in which he agreed to go to a [[Psychiatric hospital|psychiatric institution]] for an "indefinite" period of time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/01/08/transit-bandit-agrees-to-plea-deal-will-head-to-psych-ward/|title=Transit bandit agrees to plea deal, will head to psych ward|date=2018-01-08|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-01-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
==In popular culture==
After McCollum used an [[insanity defense]] based on Asperger’s, he became a [[folk hero]] to people with [[autism spectrum disorder]], especially children, celebrated for his “rebellion against what autistics often call the dreary world of the '[[neurotypical]]s'”. In spite of his diagnosis from several psychiatrists, during at least two criminal proceedings, this defense was denied as the judge ruled he was “capable of controlling his impulses”.<ref name="Osborne"/>
A ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper’s Magazine]]'' article on McCollum by Jeff Tietz was a finalist in profile writing for the 2003 [[American Society of Magazine Editors]] awards.<ref>{{Cite book |chapter=The Boy Who Loved Transit |title=The Best American Magazine Writing 2003 |editor=[[American Society of Magazine Editors]] |publisher=[[HarperCollins]] |year=2003 |isbn=0-06-056775-9}}</ref> At the 2003 [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe|Edinburgh Fringe]], Paperhat Productions of New York mounted a play by Director [[Jude Domski]] called ''Boy Steals Train'', based on McCollum’s life and letters McCollum wrote to Domski, and described as “pointing a shaming collective finger at a judiciary that refuses to recognize Darius's condition”.<ref>[http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/otherresources/fringe/fringe03-10.htm "Reviews from the 2003 Edinburgh Fringe"],</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2003/08/19/btdef19.xml&sSheet=/arts/2003/08/19/ixartleft.html |title=Edinburgh reports: American dreamers |author=Cavendish, Dominic |date=August 19, 2003 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=2007-11-06 |location=London}}</ref> The play was awarded a Fringe First by ''[[The Scotsman]]''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edinburghfestivals.co.uk/reviews.cfm?id=858032003&sid=2508 |title=Winners in the limelight |publisher=Edinburgh Festivals |work=The Scotsman |author=Eaton, Andrew |date=8 August 2003 |accessdate=2007-11-08 }}{{Dead link|date=December 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and the troupe won a Best Ensemble Acting Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sffringe.org/media/edinburgh.html |title=Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2003, Bravehearts Only |author=Weinert, Laura |publisher=BackStageWest |date=August 2003 |accessdate=2007-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325185737/http://www.sffringe.org/media/edinburgh.html |archivedate=2008-03-25 |df= }}</ref> His story was also made into a BBC radio play, broadcast on BBC Radio 4 in August 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20050814/ai_n14884010 |title="RADIO CHOICE: Afternoon Play: Boy Steals Train Monday, 2.15pm BBC", ''Independent on Sunday'' (London), August 14, 2005 |publisher=Findarticles.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-24}}</ref>
McCollum appears in Episode 2 of “The Dark End of The Spectrum,” a two-hour, two-part, radio documentary that aired on [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]’s radio show ''[[Ideas (radio show)|Ideas]]'' on June 2, 2008 and again on July 24 (Part 1) and July 31 (Part 2), 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/ideas/features/dark-end-spectrum/index.html |title=The Dark End of The Spectrum |publisher=[[CBC Radio One]] |accessdate=12 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127083730/http://www.cbc.ca/ideas/features/dark-end-spectrum/index.html |archivedate=27 January 2010}}</ref>
A documentary film about McCollum, ''[[Off the Rails (film)|Off the Rails: The Darius McCollum Story]]'', directed by Adam Irving, premiered on April 7, 2016 at the [[Full Frame Documentary Film Festival]] in [[Durham, North Carolina]].<ref>Kiah Fields, [http://thesource.com/2016/04/27/off-the-rails-director-adam-irving-talks-darius-mccollum-new-yorks-notorious-transit-imposter/ "'Off the Rails' Director Adam Irving Talks Darius McCollum, New York's Notorious Transit Imposter,"] ''[[The Source (magazine)|The Source]]'', April 27, 2016.</ref>
==See also== * [[Keron Thomas]], another train motorman impersonator * [[Neurolaw]] * [[Railfan]] * ''[[Off the Rails: The Darius McCollum Story]]''
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
